title: The art of sound
credit_line:
Edie Kurzer, Australia, 2020

Tape reels, headphones and microphones

Courtesy Gary Kurzer

NAGRA Reel to Reel Tape Recorder

Nagra, Switzerland, c. 1970s

Courtesy Paul Huntingford
brief_description: “Sound is what truly convinces the mind it is in a place,” said videogame designer Jesse Schell. “In other words, hearing is believing.” Sound is an essential part of storytelling, whether it’s ambient noise, roaring sound effects or a musical score swelling over the action. It helps communicate what’s happening, not just in narrative features and television but also in documentaries, news programmes and commercials. One of the items displayed here is a vintage Nagra audio tape recorder used by Channel 7 News in Sydney during the 1960s and early 1970s when external news footage was shot on 16mm reversal film. The syncing of sound and vision occurred back in the editing room before going to air.

constellations_other.name: News on location
constellations_other.description: The Pye Orthicon is an example of the type of television cameras used from the 1950s in Australia for both studio and outside broadcast work. Such cameras did not have have the capacity to record while out on location and so outside crews would transmit vision and sound back to studios for recording or live broadcast.
